editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

div.p: The Queen, or the excellency of her sex. An excellent old play.
Found out by a person of honour, and given to the publisher, Alexander Goughe.

lg.l: — Cedat jam Graia vetustas
Peltatas mirata nurus, jam volsca camillas
Cedat, and assyrias quae foemina flectit habenas
Fama tace, majore canon —

div.p: London, printed by T. N. for Thomas heath, in Russel street, near the piazza of Covent-garden, 1653.

div.head: To the virtuously noble and truly honourable lady, the lady Catherine Mohun, wife to the lord Warwick Mohun, baron of Okehampton, my highly honoured lord.
div.p:
Madam, emboldened by your accustomed candour and unmerited favours to things of the like nature, though disproportioned worth: (Because this excellency seems to contract those perfections her sex hath been invested with, which are as essential to your ladyship, as light to the sun) I presumed to secure this innocent orphan from the thunder-shocks of the present blasting age, under the safe protecting wreath of your name; which (I am confident) the virtues of none can more justly challenge, than those of your ladyship; who alone may seem to quicken the lifeless scene, and to demonstrate its possibility; reducing fables into practicks; by making as great honour
visible in the mirror of your daily practice. Your pardon, madam, for daring to offer such adulterate metals, to so pure a mine; for making the shadow a present to the substance; the thoughts of which was an offence, but the performance, a crime beyond the hopes of pardon. When my fate 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 me on the first, I esteemed myself unsafe (With the Politian) should I not attempt the latter, securing one error by soaring at a greater: but my duller eyes endured not the proof of so glorious a test, and the waxed juncture of my ill contrived feathers melt me into the fear of a fall: therefore (With the most desperate offenders) I cast myself on the mercy of the bench; and since I have so clement a judge as yourself, do not wholly despair of absolution, by reason my penitential acknowledgement atones part of the offence; and your remission of the whole will eternally oblige,
div.closer: Madam,the humblest of your ladyship's servants,Alexander Goughe.

div.head: To Mr. Alexander goughe upon his publishing the excellent play called the Queen; or the excellency of her sex.

lg.l: If plays be looking glasses of our lives
Where dead examples quickening art revives:
By which the players dress themselves, and we
By them may form a living imagery
To let those sullied, lie in age in dust
Or break them with pretence of fit and just.
Is a rude cruelty, as if you can
Put on the christian, and put off the man.
But must all moral handsomeness undo
And may not be divine and civil too.
What though we dare not say the poet's art
Can save while it delights, please and convert;
Or that blackfriars we hear which in this age
Fell when it was a church, not when a stage,
Or that the●n the original it is 〈◊〉. presbyters that once dwelled there,
Prayed and thrived though the playhouse were so ne●r.
Yet this we dare affirm there is more gain
In seeing men act vice than virtue fain;
And he less tempts a danger that delights
In professed players then close hypocrites,
Can there no favour to the scene be shown
Because Jack Fletcher was a Bishop's son,
Or since that order is condemned do you
Think poets therefore Antichristian too;
Is it unlawful since the stage is down
To make the press act: where no ladies swoon
At the red coats intrusion: none are stripped;
No Hystriomastix has the copy whipped
No man don women's cloth's: the guiltless press
Wears its own innocent garments: it's own dress,
Such as free nature made it: let it come
Forth midwife Goughe, securely; and if some
Like not the make or beauty of the play
Bear witness to 't and confidently say
Such a relict as once the stage did own,
Ingenuous reader, merits to be known.
Do you not hawk? Why mayn't we have a play?
Both are but recreations. You'll say
Diseases which have made physicians dumb,
By healthful excercise are overcome.
And crimes escaped all other laws, have been
Found out, and punished by the curious scene.
Are stages hurtful for the ill they teach,
And needless for the good? Which pulpits preach:
Then sports are hurtful, for the time they lose,
And needless to the good, which labour does.
Permit 'em both; or if you will allow
The mind no hawk, leave yours, and go to plough.

div.head: To Mr. Goughe, upon the publication of the play, called, the Queen, or the excellency of her sex.

lg.l: Goughe, in this little present you create
Yourself a trophy, may become a state;
For you that preserve wit, may equally
Be ranked with those defend our liberty;
And though in this ill treated scene of sense,
The general learning is but in pretence;
Or else infused like th' Eastern prophet's dove,
To whisper us, religion, honour, love;
yet the more generous race of men revives
This lamp of knowledge, and like primitives
In caves, fearless of martyrdom, rehearse
The almost breathless, now, dramatic verse.
How in the next age will our youth lament
The loss of wit, condemned to banishment.
Wit that the duller rout despise, cause they
Miss it in what their zealous priests display:
For priests in melancholy zeal admit
Only a grave formality for wit;
And would have those that govern us comply
And cherish their fallacious tyranny.
But wherein states can no advantage gain,
They harmless mirth improperly restrain;
Since men cannot be naturally called free,
If rulers claim more than security.
How happens then this rigour o'er the stage
In this restored, free, and licentious age?
For plays are images of life, and cheat
Men into virtue, and in jest repeat
What they most seriously think; nor may
We fear lest manners suffer: every day
Does higher, cunninger, more sin invent
Then any stage did ever represent.
It may indeed show evil, and affright,
As we prize day by th' ugliness of night.
But in the theatre men are easier caught,
Then by what is in clamorous pulpits taught.

sp.stage: Enter Petruchi with Buso, Pynto and Muretto, in poor habit.

sp.speaker: Petr
sp.p: All free, and all forgiven.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Bless her majesty.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Henceforth (My friends) take heed how you so hazard
Your lives and fortunes on the peevish motion
Of every discontent, you will not find
Mercy so rise at all times.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.l: Gracious sir!
Your counsel is more like an oracle,
Then man's advice, for my part I dare speak
For one, I rather will be racked asunder
Then e'er again offend so wise a majesty.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis well your lives are once more made your own;
I must attend the execution
Of your hot general each shift now for yourselves.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Is he gone, ha, ha, ha
We have the common canopy of the clear heavens
Once more o'er our heads, sirs.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.l: We are at liberty out of the hangman's clutches,
Now, mark, what good language and fair words
Will do, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Good language! O, let me go back and he hanged, rather than live within the rotten infection of thy cankered breath; the poison of a flatterer's tongue is a thousand times more deadly, than the twinges of a rope; thou birth of an unlucky planet:
I abhor thee.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Fie, fie! Can you rail on your friends thus.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Friends, my friend captain, come from that slippery eel, captain.
His very cradle was in dirt and mud.
His milk the oil of serpents; his mother a mangy mermaid, and a male crocodile begat him.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: This needs not sweet, signior Pynto.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Sweet signior? Sweet cog a foist, go hang thyself, thou'dst jeer the very rags I wear off my back with thy fustians of sweet, precious, unmatchable, rare, wise, judicious, heigh do! Pox on thee; sirrah, sirrah, hast not thou many a time and often devoured a whole table of mine, garnished with plenty, nay; variety of good wholesome fare, under the colour of telling news with a roughy compliment?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Good fare of thine!

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Nay, dear gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Mine! I mine, sycophant, I (●ost mark me) to supply 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 a whole study of 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 ri●h that they might have set up a coronation of almanac makers; and what had I in return? But protestations, (Hearest thou this maunderer) that I was, for learning, the soundest; for bounty, the royalest; for discourse, the sententioust; for behaviour, the absolutest 〈◊〉 for all endowments of mind and body, the most accomplished that nature ever called her workmanship: but thou dog, thou scoundrel, my beggary was the fruits of thy flattery. Stand off, rascal, off.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: This is excellent faith;

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: How, how! I flatter ye? What thee, thee? A poor lousy uncloakt imposter, a deceitful, cozening, cheating, dull decoying fortune teller; thou pawn books; thou, patched out of an old shepherd's calendar, that discoursest in time of the change of the weather.

And whose were thy Ephemerides? Why, impudence, wert thou ever worth erra Pater's prognostication? Thou learned! In what? By filching, stealing, borrowing, eating, collecting, and counting with as weather-wise idiots as thyself; once in twelve months thou wert indeed delivered, (Like a big bellied wife) of a two penny almanac, at easter. A hospital boy in a blue coat shall transcribe as much in six hours to serve all the year.
Thou a table of meat, yes, astronomers fare, air; or at a feast upon high holy days, three red sprats in a dish; that was held gluttony too.
I flatter thee? Thou learned?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Rascal, cannibal that feedest upon man's flesh.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Nay, pray, pray heartily gentlemen; in good earnest, and as I live, and by this hand now —

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Right thou puttest me in mind what I should call thee; who was't the cause of all the late insurrection for which we were all like to be hanged, and our brave general Alphonso is this day to suffer for; who but thou, forsooth; the influences of the stars, the conjunction of the planets, the prediction of the celestial bodies were peremptory, that if a' would but attempt a civil commotion, a' should (I marry should a') be straight crowned present King of Arragon. Now your gipsonly may i'th moon, your divination hath fairly mounted him; poor gentleman, he's sure to leave his head in pawn for giving credit to thy prognosticating ignorance.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: I scorn thee, parasite.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: You are a stinking starved 〈◊〉 - gu● star-gazer. I● that ●attery or no.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: ●oot, what do you mean, signior Pynto, signior Muretto?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: I will be revenged and watch my time, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: This is strange my master, to be so here the place of execution and prattle so 〈◊〉; come signior Pynto; indeed la you shall shake hands.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Let me alone, you're a foolish captain. Muretto, I will display thee for a —

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Hang thyself, I care not for thee this.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Foolish captain, foolish captain, hark ye, Pynto, there's no such good meaning in that word.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: A parrot can echo, talk to scholars so.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: A proper scholar, stitched up of waste paper.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Sneaks, if I be a fool, I'll bang out the wits of some of your noddles, or dry bastinado your sides.
Ye dogret, mangy scabbed owlaglasses,
I'll maul ye, so I will.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Captain, sweet captain, nay, look, now will you put your discretion to coxcombs?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Yes, the proudest coxcombs of 'em all, if I be provoked; foolish, flesh and blood cannot endure't.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: So, goodman sky walker, you have made a trim hand on't, to chase yourself into a threat cutting.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: I will shred you both so small, that a very butcher shall shred Spanish needles, with every fillet of your itchy flesh; call me foolish, ye whelps-moils; my father was a corn cutter, and my mother a muscle woman, 'tis known what I am, and I'll make you know what I am, if my choler be raised but one inch higher.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Well, I see Mars and Saturn, were thy planets.
Thou art a valiant soldier, and there's no dealing with ye. For the captain's sake, I will abate my indignation, Muretto. But —

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: But i'thy face, I'll have no butts, 'sbones , the black guard is more honourably sured then any of us three. Foolish, foolish, will never out of my head while I live.

sp.speaker: Muret:
sp.p: Long life, eternal prosperity, the blessing o'th heavens, and honours of the earth, crown the glorious merits of the incomparable, captain don Velasco.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: The chime goes again, captain.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Who are these poor creatures, Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: My lord, I know them now, they are some of the late mutineers, whom you (When you, took Alphonso prisoner) presented to the rigor of the law, but since they are by the Queen's pardon set at liberty.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I should know yonder fellow.
Your name is Bufo, if I mistake not.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: My name is my own name, sir, and Bufo is my name, sir, if any man shall deny't, I dare challenge him in defence of my godfathers that gave me that name, sir; and what say you to that, sir?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: A shallow, unbrained, weak, foolish fellow, and so forth: your lordship understands me;
But for our parts my good lord —

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Well, gentlemen, I cannot tell you now,
That any poor endeavours of mine own
Can work Alphonso's peace, yet I have spoke
And kneeled and sued for his reprieve. The Queen
Hath heard, but will not grant; this is the day,
And this the time, and place, where he must render
The forfeit of his life unto the law.
I only can be sorry.

sp.stage: Enter Petruchi, after the hangman bearing the axe before Alphonso, with officers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Alphonso, here's the place, and this the hour;
Your doom is past, and now the sword of law
Must cut the vein that swelled with such a frenzy
Of dangerous blood against your Queen and country.
Prepare yourself, 'tis now too late to hope.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Petruchi, what is done I did, my ground
Was pity of my country, not malice to't.
I sought to free wracked Arragon from ruin,
Which a fond woman's government must bring.
O had you and the nobles of this land,
A touch but of the miseries, her weakness
Must force ye of necessity to feel,
You would with me have bent your naked swords
Against this female mistress of the crown,
And not have been such children to have fawned
upon a girl's nod.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You are distracted;
She is our lawful sovereign, we her subjects.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Subjects, Petruchi, abjects, and so live;
I come to die, on to the execution.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Here's a high saturnal spirit, captain.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Pox o'spirits when they mount a man to the hangman's mercy, I do not like such spirits, let me rather be a moon calf.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: I come to bid farewell, and in farewell,
To excuse my much ill fortune, for believe, sir,
I hold my victory an overthrow.
To tell you how incessantly I plied
Her grace, for your remission, were as useless
As was my suit, I sorry for your youth.
Let's part yet reconciled.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: With all my heart;
It is my glory, that I was reduced
By the best man at arms, that ever knighthood
Hath styled a soldier — alas! What souls are those?
Now, now, in seeing them I die too late.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: O brave general, oh noble general, we are still the rags of the old regiment. The truth on't is, we were loath to leave thee, till thy head and shoulders parted companies. But sweet good dear general take courage, what, we are all mortal men, and must every one pass this way, as simple as we stand here.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, farewell; the Queen is merciful in sparing you; I have not ought to give thee but my last thanks.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: B●rto 'Giving, our clothes are paid for, and a day will come shall quit us all.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Art thou, and thou there too; well, leave thy art,
And do not trust the fixions of the stars,
They spoke no truth by me: my lord Velasco,
That creature, there, Muretto, is a man
Of honest heart, for my sake take him to you:
And now soft, peace to all.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: I will burn my books, forswear the liberal sciences, and that is my resolution.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Go thy way for the arrantest general, that ever led crew of brave Sketdreus.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Will you make ready, sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Petruchi, yes, I have a debt to pay, 'tis nature's due.
Fellow before thou ask my pardon, take it;
Be sure and speedy in thy fatal blow.

sp.speaker: Hangman
sp.p: Never fear clean shaving, sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: May I have leave to meditate?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: A gallant resolution, even in death.

sp.stage: Enter Queen, Collummello, Almada, Herophil, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Stay execution 'tis her highness' pleasure;
Alphonso rise ye, and behold the Queen.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Beshrew the voice of majesty, my thoughts
Were fixed upon an upper region now,
And traffic not with earth; alas great woman,
What newer tyranny, what doom, what torments
Are borrowed from the conclave of that hell.
Where legions of worse devils, then are in hell
Keep revels, a proud woman's heart. What plagues
Are broached from thence to kill me?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: The moon is now lady of the ascendant, and the man will die raving.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Fie, Alphonso,
Will you commit another strange commotion
With your unruly tongue. And what you cannot
Perform in act, attempt to do in words?
A dying man be so uncharitable.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Cry mercy, she is Queen of Arragon,
and would with her own eyes (Instead of masks
And courtly sports) behold an act of death.
Queen, welcome, Queen, here quaff my blood like wine;
And live a brave she tyrant.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Alas, poor man.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Poor man, that looks on me, delighted to destroy me.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Good boy i'faith, by this hand of speaks just as I would do, for all that he is so near being made puddings meat.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: You are sorry for your late desperate rudeness, are you not?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By all my miseries these taunts are cruelty.
Worse than the hangman's axe, I am not sorry,
Nay more, will not be sorry, know from me
I hate your sex in general, not you
As you're a Queen, but as you're a woman:
Had I a term of life could last for ever,
And you could grant it, yes, and would, yet all
Or more should never reconcile my heart
To any she alive — are ye resolved?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: His spirit flies out in his daring language.
Alphonso though the law require thy head,
Yet I have mercy where I see just cause:
You'll be a new man?

sp.speaker: Alph
sp.l: Oh! a woman's tongue
Is sharper than a pointed steel; tender, madam,
I kiss your royal hand, and call you fair,
Assure this noble, this uncovered, presence,
That richest virtue is your bosom's tenant,
That you are absolutely great and good;
I'll flatter all the vices of your sex,
Protesting men are monsters, women angels,
No light ones, but full weighty, nature's best,
I'll proclaim lust a pity, pride a handsomeness.
Deceit ripeness of wit, bold scandalous scolding,
A bravery of spirit; bloody cruelty,
Masculine justice; more I will maintain
That Queens are chief for rule, you chief of Queens,
If you'll but give me leave to die in peace.
Pray give me leave to die. Pray good now do,
What think ye, 'tis a royal grant; henceforth
Heaven be the rest you chose, but never come at.
A kind farewell to all.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Can you endure
To let a rebel prate? off with his head,
And let him then dispute.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I should have used
The privilege of time, had I known this.
You must not talk so loud.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: My lords, a word: what if we pardoned him, I think the nearness of his arrival to the stroke of death, will ever be a warning to his loyalty.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: How pardon him! What means your majesty?
What can you hope from one so wholly drowned
In melancholy and sour discontent;
That should he share the crown, a' would employ
On none but apes and flatterers.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Spare, my lord
Such liberal censure, rather rein the fury
Of justice, then so spur it on. Great mistress,
I will not plead my services, but urge
The glories you may challenge by your mercy.
It will be a most sweet becoming act
To set you in the chronicles of memory.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Velasco, thou art not more brave in arms
To conquer with thy valour, than thy courtesy.
Alphonso, take thy life, who took thee prisoner,
Is now become thy spokesman.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Phew, mock not
Calamity so grossly.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: You are too desperate: the Queen hath freely pardoned you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: And more to purchase kind opinion of thy sex, ourselves will lend our help. Lords, all your hands.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: But is the Queen in earnest?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: It becomes her, mercy is God like.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Officers be gone.
Such objects for a royal presence are
Unfit, here kiss our hand, we dare conceive
That 'twas thy height of youth, not hate of us
Drew thee to those attempts, and both we pardon.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Do not the stars run a wrong bias now, signior Pynto?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Venus is lady of the ascendant, man. I knew if once he pass the fatal hour, the influence would work another way.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Very likely, your reasons are infallible.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: What can our favours challenge.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: More true service,
True faith, true love, than I have words to utter.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Which we accept, lead on, here ends this strife,
When law craves justice, mercy should grant life.
sp.stage: Exit all but Pynto and his fellows.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Go thy ways for a sure sound brained piece whilst thou livest; Pynto, say I, now, now, am I an ass, now my masters, hang yourselves, is foot, I'll stand to't; that man whoever he be, (Better or worse, all's one) who is not star wise, is nature's fool; your astronomer hath the heavens, the whole globe of the earth, and the vast gulf of the sea itself, for his proper kingdom, his fee-simple, his own inheritance, who looks any higher than the top of a steeple, or a may pool, is worthy to die in a ditch. But to know the conjunctions of the planets, the influences of the celestial body, the harmony of the spheres, frost and snow, hail and tempests, rain and sunshine, nay, life and death; here's cunning, to be deep in speculation, to be groping the secrets of nature.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: O, sir, there, there, there.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Let me alone, I say it myself, I know I am a rare fellow; why, look, look ye, we are all made, or let me be stewed in star-shut; pish, I am confident, and we shall all mount, believe it.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Shall we, nay, than I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Friar bacon was but a brazen head, in comparison of him.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: But why should you not have said so much before, goodman jolt-head?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Nay, look ye, captain, there's a time for all things.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: For all this, what will become of us; is the sign lucky to venture the begging of a cast suit? Let me be resolved of that once.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: 'Twas wisely urged, captain.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Man's richest ornament is his nakedness, gentlemen, variety of clothing is the surquedry of fools; wise men have their proper solace in the linings of their minds; as for fashions, 'tis a disease for a horse.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Never richer stuff came from man.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: 'zookes, 'tis a scurvy, a pocky, and a naked answer; a plague of all your sentences; whilst I am like to starve with hunger and cold,

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: By your leave, gentlemen, the lord Alphonso hath sent you this purse of gold, commands ye to put yourselves into costly suits, and repair to court;

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How! To court!

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Where you may happily see him crowned King, for that's the common report; I was charged to urge you to be very speedy: farewell, gentlemen .

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: What think ye now, my hearts of gold?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Hearts of gold indeed now, signior.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Pish, I am a coxcomb, I; o, the divinity of —

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Bawl no more the weather's cold, I must have utensicles, follow your leader, ho.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Prithee persuade me not.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: You'll lose your honour.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I'd rather lose my honour then my faith: oh, Lodovico, thou art witness with me, that I have sworn, and pledged my heart, my truth to her deserving memory, whose beauty, is through the world unfollowed.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Here the wisdom of sword men, they deal all by strength not policy. What exercise shall be feigned, let me know that?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Excuse, why, Lodovico, I am sick, and I am sick indeed, sick to the soul.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: For a decayed tilter, or a known coward, this were tolerable now: but to, the business; I have solicited your widow.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Will she nor speak with me?

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Young widows, and grave old ones two, by your leave care not so much for talking; if you come once to them you must do, and do, and do again, again, and again, all's two little, you'll find it.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Come, friend, you mock my miseries

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: It's a fine laughing matter when the best and most approved soldier of the world, should be so heartsick for love of a placket: well I have sent your wise servant (For fools are best to be trusted in women's things) to my cousin Shaparoon's, and by him your second letter, you shall shortly hear what news: my cousin is excellently traded in these mortal businesses of flesh and blood, and will hardly come of with two denials.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: If she prevail, Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: What then? Ply your occupation when you come to't, 'tis a fit season of the year, women are honey moon if a man could jump with them at the instant, and prick 'em in the right vain; else this Queen would never have saved a traitor from the block, and suddenly made him her King and husband. But no more of that, there's danger in't; you're sick you say?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Pierced through with very darts, much worse than death.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Why your only present remedy is, then as soon as you can, to quench those fires in the watery channels of qualification: soft, no more words, behold a prodigy.

sp.stage: Flourish. enter Colonnello, Almada bore, Alphonso and the Queen crowned, Herophil, Petruchi with a guard, the King and Queen take their states.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long live Alphonso King of Arragon.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Then we are sovereign.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: As free, as I by birth:
I yield to you (My lord) my crown, my heart,
My people, my obedience; in exchange
What I demand is love.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You cannot miss it;
There is but one thing that all humane power
Or malice of the devil could set a broach,
To work on for a breach 'twixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: One thing! Why, is there one thing then, my lord?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Yes, and 'tis only this; you're still a woman.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: A woman! Said you so, sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I confess
You have deserved more service, more regard
From me, in my particular, than life
Can thank you for; and that you may conceive
My fair acknowledgement; although 'tis true,
I might command; yet I will make a suit,
An earnest suit t'ee.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: It must then be granted.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: That to redeem a while some serious thoughts
Which have misdeemed your sex. You'll be content
I be a married bachelor one seven-night.
You cannot but conceive.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Fine work.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Alas my lord, this needs no public mention.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nay, madam, hear me, that our our courts be kept
Under a several roof; that you and I
May not for such a short time, come together.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Your patience, madam,
You interrupt me, that no message pass
Of commendation, questioning our healths,
Our sleeps, our actions, or what else belongs
To common courtesy, 'twixt friend, and friend.
You must be pleased to grant it, I'll have it so.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: No message of commends!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Phew, you demur,
It argues your distrust.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I am content
The King should be obeyed. Pray heaven all be well.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Velasco, thou were't he didst conquer me,
Didst take me prisoner? were't in that the means
To raise me up thus high. I thank thee for't;
I thought to honour thee in a defence
Of the Queen's beauty; but we'll now deferr't.
Yet hand your mistress, lead her to the court,
We and our lords will follow, there we'll part;
A seven days' absence cannot seem but short.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: And as I said (Nay pray my friend be covered) the business hath been soundly followed on my part. Yet again, in good sooth, I cannot abide you should stand bare before me to so little purpose.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Manners is a jewel (Madam) and as for standing bare, I know there is some difference, the putting down of a man's cap, and the putting down of his breeches before a reverend gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: You speak very properly, there is a great deal of difference indeed. But to come to the point; fie, what a stir I had to make her to receive the letter, and when she had received it, to open it, and then to read it; nay, to read it again and again; that as I am a very woman, a man might have wrong my smock dropping wet, with the pure sweat that came from my body. Friend, I took such pains with her. O my conscience, to bear a child at those years would not trouble me half so much as the delivery of that letter did.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: A manchild of my age perhaps, madam, would not.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Yet that were a sore burden for one that is not used to't, I may tell you. O these coy girls are such wild cattle to have dealing with.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: What ancient madams cannot do one way, let them do another; she's a rank jade that being passed the breeder, cannot kick up her heels, wince, and cry wee-hee: good examples cannot choose from ones elders, but work much to the purpose, being well plied, and in season.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: In season? True, that's a chief thing; yes, I'll assure you my friend, I am but entering into eight and twenty.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p:
Wants somewhat of that too, I take it; I warrant ye your mark appears
yet to be seen for proof of your age, as plain as when you were but fifteen.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Truly, if it were well searched, I think it does.
Your name is Mopas, you told me?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Mopas my name is, and yours madam Shaparoon I was told.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: A right madam born I can assure ye.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Your ancestors will speak that, for the Shaparoons have ever took place of the best french-hoods in the parish; ever since the first addition.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: All this with a great deal of modesty I must confess. Ud's pittikins, stand by, aside a little: see where the lady coms; do not appear before you are called, in any case: but mark how I will work her like wax.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Your servant in all commands Velasco. So, and I am resolved to put ye to the test, servant, for your free fools heart, ere I give you the slip, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Your ladyship hath considered the premises ere this time, at full, I hope.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: O, Shaparoon, you keep true sentinel, what? I must give certain answer; must I not?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Nay, madam, you may choose, 'tis all in your ladyship's discreet consideration. The sum of all is, that if you show him not some favour, he is no long lives man.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Very well; how long have you been a factress for such merchants, Shaparoon.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: O my religion! I a factress? I am even well enough served for my good will; and this is my requital. Factress, quoth you?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Come, your intercession shall prevail, which is his letter carrier?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: At your ladyship's service.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Your lord Velasco sent you?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Most true, sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: What place hold you about him?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I am his drugster, madam.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Being hard bound with melancholy, I give him a purge, with two or three soluble stools of laughter.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Belike you are his fool, or his jester.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Jester if you please, but not fool, madam; for babbles belong to fools, and they are then only fit for lady's secrecies, not for lords.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: But is he indeed sick of late?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Alas good heart, I suffer for him.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: By your leave lady, without ceremony, you know me, and may guess my errand.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Yet more trouble, nay, than I shall be hailshot.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: To be brief. By the honours of a good name, you are a dry-skinned widow, and did not my haste concern the life of the noblest gentleman in Europe, I would as much scorn employments of this nature to you, as I do a proud woman of your condition.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I marry here's one will thunder her widowhood into flitters: stand to't, signior, I am your second.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Sir you're uncivil to exclaim against a lady in her own house.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: A lady, yet a paraquito, popinjay, your whole worth lies in your gay out side, and your squawling tongue.
A wagtail is a glorious fowl in respect of many of ye.
Though most of ye are in nature as very fowl as wagtails.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Are such as you the lord Velasco's agents in his hot affection?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Sweet cousin, Lodovico, pray now, the lady is most virtuously resolved.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Hark ye middle-aged countess, do not take another's tale into your mouth, I have occasion to use you in private, and can find you work enough myself, a word in your ear.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p:
I protest, I meant more noble
answer for his satisfaction, then ever your railing language shall force from me.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Were I the man that doted on you, I would take a shorter course with you, than to come humbly whining to your sweet — pox of all such ridiculous foppery — I would —

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Weep yourself to death, and be chronicled among the regiment of kind tender hearted souls.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Indeed, forsooth, I would not; what, for a widow one that hath jumped the old moils trot, so oft, that the sciatica founders her yet in both her thighs.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: You abuse me grossly.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: One that hath been so often drunk with satiety of pleasure, that fourteen husbands are but as half a draught to quench her thrust in an afternoon.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I will no longer endure ye.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: For you, you? That are neither noble, wife, rich, fair, nor well-favoured. For you?

sp.speaker: Mop:
sp.p: You are all these, if you can keep your own counsel and let nobody know, mistress madam.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Nay I am so persuaded, and assure yourself nobody shall know.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Yet forsooth, must you be the only precious piece the lord Velasco must adore, must die for. But I vow, if he do miscarry, (As I fear he cannot recover.)

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Goodness forbid, alas! Is he sick, sir?

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Excellent dissimulation! Yes sure, he is sick, and an everlasting silence strike you dumb that are the cause on't. But, as I said, if he do go the wrong way, as I love virtue, your ladyship shall be ballasted through all Christendom, and sung to sciroy tunes, and your picture drawn over every ballad, sucking of rotten eggs among weasels.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Pray give me leave; is lord Velasco sick? And lies there ought in me to comfort, or recover him?

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Marry does there, the more infidel he: and what of all this now?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: 'Wonders, either go and visi him, or admit him to visit you; these are mighty favours are they not?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Why, good sir, I will grant the later willingly; he shall be kindly welcome.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: And laughed at while he is here: shall a not?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: What would you have me say? My best entertainment shall be open to him; I will discourse to him freely, if he requires it privately: I will be all what in honour I should.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Certify him so much by letter.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: That cannot stand with my modesty, my word and truth shall be my gage.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Enough, do this, and by this hand I'll ask you pardon for my rudeness, and ever heartily honour you.

sp.speaker: Map.
sp.p: I shall hear from you when my leisures serves.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Most assuredly. Good destinies speed your journey.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: All happiness ride ever before you, your disgraces behind you, and and full pleasure in the midst of ye.

sp.stage: Enter Bufo in fresh apparel, ushering: Herophil.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: My over kind, captain, what would you say?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Why, mistress, I would say, as a man might say forsooth, indeed I would say.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: What, captain?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Even whatsoever you would have me to say, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: If that be all, pray say nothing.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Why look ye, mistress, all what I say if you mark it well, is just nothing; as for example, to tell you that you are fair, is nothing, for you know it yourself; to say you were honest, were an indignity to your beauty, and upon the matter nothing, for honesty in a fair woman is as good as nothing.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: That is somewhat strange to be proved.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: To a good wit, dear mistress, nothing's impossible.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Sure the court and your new clothes have infected you: would I were a purse of gold, for your sake, captain, to reward your wit.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: I would you were, mistress, so you were not counterfeit metal, I should soon try you on the too true touchstone of my affections, indeed forsooth.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Well, witty captain, for your love I must pass away in debt, but will not fail to think on't. But now I am in haste.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: If you would but grant me but one poor request, before you go, I should soon dispatch and part.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Name it, captain.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Truly, and as I live, 'tis a very small trifle for your part, all things considered.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: But cannot you tell what it is?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: That were a fine jest indeed, why, I would desire, entreat, and beseech you.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: There you have it, and thank you too.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Why, to do with you, forsooth, to do with you.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: In plain words, I would commit with you, or as the more learned phrase it, if you be pleased to consent, I would ravish you.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Fie, fie, captain, so uncivil, you made me blush.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Do I say; why, I am glad I have it for you: soldiers are hot upon service, mistress, and a wise man's bolt is soon shot; as the proverb says:

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Good captain, keep up your bolt till I am at leisure to stand fair for your mark. If the court stallions prove all so rank, I will vow all to ride henceforth upon an ass; so, captain, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Farewell heartily to you forsooth.
Go thy ways for as true a mistress as ever fouled clean nappery. This same whoreson court diet, cost, lodging, change of clothes, and ease, have addicted me villanously to the itch of concupiscence.

sp.stage: Enter Alphonso; Pynto and Muretto complementing on either side of him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: They all shall not entreat me.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Your majesty were no King, if your own will were not your own law.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Always, my lord, observing the domination of the planets: as if Mars and Venus being in conjunction, and their influence working upon your frailty; then in any case you must not resist the motion of the celestial bodies.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: All which (Most gracious sovereign) this most famous scholar will at a minute foretell.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: All hail to the King himself, my very good liege, lord, and most gracious benefactor.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What need I other counsellors then these.
Shall I be forced to be a woman's slave? That may live free, and hate their fickle sex.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: O 'tis a glorious virtue in so magnificent a prince to abstain from the sensual surfeits of fleshly and wanton appetites.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I find the inclination of such follies.
Why, what are women?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Very pleasant pretty necessary toys, an't please your majesty; I myself could pass the time with them, as occasion might serve, eight and forty hours out right, one to one always provided.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Yet of all the seven planets, there are but two women among them, and one of them two is chaste, which is, as good as if she were a boy.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: That is not to be questioned; the best of women are but troubles and vexations, 'tis man that retains all true perfection, and of all men your majesty.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p:
Ye are too rude to enter on our privacies,
without our licence, speak, your business lords.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: We came from your most virtuous Queen.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: No more.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A month is well nigh passed, and yet you slack
Your love to her: what mean you, sir, so strangely
To slight a wife whose griefs grow now too high,
For womanhood to suffer.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Is't your pleasure
To admit her to your bosom?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You're too saucy.
Return, and quickly too, and tell her thus;
If she intend to keep her in our favour,
Let us not see her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Say you so, great sir;
You speak it but for trial

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: O, sir, remember what you are, and let not
The insinuations of these servile creatures,
Made only men by you, sooth and traduce
Your safety to a known and wilful danger.
Fix in your thoughts the ruin you have 'scaped;
Who freed you; who hath raised you to this height,
And you will then awake your judgement's eye:
The commons murmur, and the streets are filled
With busy whispers: yet in time recall
Your violence.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: As I am King, the tongue forfeits his head that speaks another word.

sp.speaker: Muretto,
sp.p: Talk we not now like a King?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Like one that hath the whole world for his proper monarchy, and it becomes you royally.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: The Queen, and my mistress; oh brave, we shall have some doings hard to hand now, I hope.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What means the woman? Ha! is this the duty
Of a good wife, we sent not for you, did we?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The more my duty that I came unsent for;
Wherein my gracious lord have I offended?
Wherein have I transgressed against thy laws
Oh sacred marriage? To be sequestered
In the first spring and April of my joys
From you, much dearer to me, than my life?
By all the honour of a spotless bed,
Show me my fault, and I will turn away,
And be my own swift executioner.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I take that word. Know then you married me
Against my will, and that's your fault

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Alas! Against your will? I dare not contradict
What you are pleased to urge. But by the love
I bore the King of Arragon, (An oath
As great as I can swear by) I conceived
Your words to be true speakers of your heart,
And I am sure they were; you swore they were.
How should I but believe, that loved so dear?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Come then you are a trifler, for by this
I know you love me not.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is that your fear?
Why la now, lords, I told you that the King
Made our division but a proof of faith.
Kind husband, now I'm bold to call you so;
Was this your cunning to be jealous of me
So soon? We women are fine fools
To search men's pretty subtleties.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: You'll scarce find it so

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: She would persuade me strangely.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Prithee, sweet heart,
Force not thyself to look so sadly; troth
It suits not with thy love, 'tis well. Was this
your se'ennight's respite? Yet, as I am a Queen,
I feared you had been in earnest.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Earnest: hence
Monstrous enchantress, by the death I owe
To nature, thou appearest to me in this
More impudent than impudence, the tide
Of thy luxurious blood is at the full;
And cause thy raging pleurisy of lust
Cannot be sated by our royal warmth,
Thou triest all cunning petulant charms to raise
A wanton devil up in our chaste breast.
But we are canon-proof against the shot
Of all thy arts.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Was't you spoke that, my lord?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Phaeton is just over the orb of the moon, his horses are got loose, and the heavens begin to grow into a combustion.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I'll sooner dig a dungeon in a molehill,
And hide my crown there, that both fools and children
May trample o'er my royalty, then ever
Lay it beneath an antic woman's feet.
Couldst thou transshape thyself into a man,
And with it be more excellent than man
Can be; yet since thou were't a woman once,
I would renounce thee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Let the King remember
It is the Queen he speaks too.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Pish, I know
She woúld be well contented but to live
Within my presence; not for love to me,
But that she might with safety of her honour,
Mix with some hot veined lecher, whose prone lust
Should feed the rank impostume of desires,
And get a race of bastards, to whose birth
I should be thought the dad. But thou, thou woman,
Ere I will be the cloak to thy false play,
I'll couple with a witch, a hag; for if
Thou canst live chaste, live by thy sel like me.
Or if thou wouldst persuade me that thou lovest me,
See me no more, never. From this time forth
I hate thy sex; of all thy sex, thee worst.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Madam, dear madam, yet
Take comfort, time will work all for the best

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Where must I go?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You're in your own kingdom, 'tis your birthright,
We all your subjects; not a man of us,
But to the utmost of his life, will right
Your wrongs against this most unthankful King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Away, ye are all traitors to profane
His sacred merits with your bitter terms.
Why, am I not his wife? A wife must bear
Withal what likes her lord t'upbraid her with,
And yet 'tis no injustice. What was't he said?
That I no more should see him, never, never.
There I am quite divorced from all my joys,
From all my paradise of life. Not see him?
'Twas too unkind a task. But he commanded
I cannot but obey. Where's Herophil?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Here madam.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Go hang my chamber all with mourning black;
Seal up my windows, let no light survey,
The subtle tapers that must eye my griefs.
Get from me lords, I will defy ye all,
You're men, and men (Oh me) are all unkind.
Come hither Herophil, spread all my robes,
My jewels and apparel on the floor,
And for a crown get me a willow wreath:
No, no, that's not my colour, buy me a veil
engrained in tawny. Alas, I am forsaken,
And none can pity me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: By all the faith
I owe to you my sovereign, if you please
To enjoy me any service, I will prove
Most ready and most true,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Why should the King
Despise me? I did never cross his will,
Never gainsaid his, yea; yet sure I fear
He hath some ground for his displeasure.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.l: None,
Unless because you saved him from the block.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Art thou a prattler too? Peace, Herophil,
Tempt not a desperate woman. No man here
Dares do my last commends to him.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: If your excellent majesty please to repose confidence in me; I will not only deliver him your commendations, but think myself highly dishonoured, if he return not his back to you by letter.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Off beast, made all of baseness, do not grieve
Calamity, or as I am a knight,
I'll cut thy tongue out.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.l: Sweet signior, I protest —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Madam, believe him not, he is a parasite;
Yet one the King doth dote on.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Then beshrew ye,
You had not used him gently, had I known't,
I would have kneeled before him, and have sent
A handful of my tears unto the King.
Away, my lords, here is no place to revel
In our discomfits. Herophil, let's haste,
That thou and I may heartily like widows
Bewail my bridal mocked virginity.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Let's follow her my lords; I fear too late
The King will yet repent these rude divisions.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Compliment? 'tis for barber's shops; know your own worth, you speak to a frail commodity; and barter't away roundly, my lord.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: She promised free discourse?

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: She did: are ye answered?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Madam, my lord Velasco is come, use him nobly and kindly, or — I say no more.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: To a poor widow's house my lord is welcome.
Your lordship honours me in this favour; in what thankful entertainment I can, I shall strive to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Your sweet lordship is most heartily welcome, as I may say.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Instead of a letter, madam good-face, on my lord's behalf, I am bold to salute you.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Madam Salassa, not distrusting the liberty you granted, now you and my lord are in you own house, we will attend ye in the next room; away, cousin; follow, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: It is a woman part to come behind.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: But for two men to pass in before one woman, 'tis too much a conscience; on reverend antiquity.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: What is your Lordship's pleasure?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: To rip up
A story of my fate. When by the Queen
I was employed against the late commotioners,
(Of whom the now King was chief leader) then
In my return you pleased to entertain me
Here in your house.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Much good may it do your lordship.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: But then, what conquest gained I by that conquest,
When here mine eyes, and your commanding beauty
Made me a prisoner to the truest love,
That ever warmed a heart.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Who might that be?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: You, lady, are the deity I adore,
have kneeled too in my heart, have vowed my soul to,
In such a debt of service, that my life
Is tenant to your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Phew, my lord;
It is not nobly done to mock me thus.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Mock you? Most fair Salassa, if e'er truth
Dwelled in a tongue, my words and thoughts are twins.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: You wrong your honour in so mean a choice.
Can it be though, that that brave man, Valasco,
Sole champion of the world, should look on me?
On me, a poor lone widow? 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Valas.
sp.l: I am poorer
In my performance now, then ever; so poor,
That vows and protestations want fit credit
With me to vow the least part of a service
That might deserve your favour.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: You are serious?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Lady, I wish that for a present trial,
Against the custom of so sweet a nature,
You would be somewhat cruel in commands.
You dare not sist the honour of my faith
By any strange injunction, which the speed
Of my glad undertaking should not cheerfully
Attempt, or perish in the sufferance of it.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: You promise lordly.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: You too much distrust
The constancy of truth.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: It were unnoble,
On your part to demand a gift of bounty,
More than the freedom of a fair allowance,
Confirmed by modesty and reason's warrant
Might without blushing yield unto.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: O, fear not,
For my affections aim at chaste contents;
Not at unruly passions of desire.
I only claim the title of your servant,
The flight of my ambitions soars no higher,
Then living in your grace, and for encouragement
To quicken my attendance now and then
A kind unravished kiss.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: That's but a fee,
Due to a fair deserver: but admit
I grant it, and you have it; may I then
Lay a light burden on you.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: What is possible
For me to venture on, by how much more
It carries danger in't; by so much more
My glory's in the achievement.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: I must trust ye.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: By all the virtues of a soldier's name,
I vow and sware.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Enough, I take that oath: and thus myself first do confirm your warrant.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I feel new life within me.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Now be steward,
For your own store, my lord, and take possession
Of what you have purchased freely.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: With a joy.
As willing as my wishes can arrive at.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: So, I may claim your oath now.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I attend it.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Velasco, I do love thee, and am jealous
Of thy spirit, which is hourly apt
To catch at actions; if I must be mistress
Of thee and my own will, thou must be subject
To my improvements.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: 'Tis my soul's delight.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: You're famed the only fighting sir alive;
But what's this; if you be not safe to me.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: By all —

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: You shall not sware, take heed of perjury.
So much I fear your safety, that I command,
for two years space, you shall not wear a sword,
A dagger, or stelletto; shall not fight
On any quarrel be it ne'er so just.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Lady!

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.p: Hear more yet; if you be baffled, railed at, scorned, mocked struck, baffled, kicked,

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: (Oh lady!)

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Spit on, reviled, challenged, provoked by fools,
Boys, antics, cowards.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: ('tis intolerable.)

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: I charge you (By your oath) not to reply
In word, deed, look: and lastly, I conjure ye
Never to show the cause to any living
By circumstance or by equivocation;
Nor till two years expire to motion love.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Why do you play the tyrant thus?

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: 'Tis common
T'observe how love hath made a coward valiant;
But that a man as daring as Velasco,
Should to express his duty to a mistress,
Kneel to his own disgraces, and turn coward,
Belongs to me and to my glories only;
I'm empress of this miracle. Your oath
Is past, if you will lose yourself you may.
How d'ye, sir?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Woman thou art vain and cruel.

sp.speaker: Salas.
sp.l: Will't please your lordship taste a cup of wine,
Or stay and sup, and take a hard bed here?
Your friends think we have done strange things this while.
Come let us walk like lovers: I am pitiful,
I love no quarrels.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Triumph in my ruins.
There is no act of folly but is common
In use and practise to a scornful woman.

sp.stage: Enter Alphonso, Almada, Muretto, Bufo, Pynto, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You have prevailed, yet ere you came (My lord)
Muretto, here this right, right, honest man
Confirmed me thoroughly, now to witness further
With what a gratitude I love the Queen.
Reach me a bowl of wine.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Your majesty more honours me, in making me the messenger of this most happy concord, than addition of greatness can express.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.l: I ever told you,
How you would his grace, inclined at last

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: The very Jove of benignity, by whose gentle aspect the whole sphere of this court and kingdom are (Like the lesser orbs) moved round in the harmony of affability.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My lord Almado, health unto your mistress,
A hearty health, a deep one.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Upon my knee
My duty gladly answers

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Give him wine.
There's not a man whoever in our court
(Greater or meaner) but shall pledge this health,
In honour of our Queen, our virtuous Queen.
Commend us, and report us as you find.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Great sir, I shall with joy.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Bufo and Pynto,
All in, and drink, drink deep, let none be spared,
Comers or goers, none.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Away my hearts.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p:
We'll tickle it till the welkin
blussle again, and all the fixed stars dance the old measures.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: I shall attend to wait upon your lordship to the caroche.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: So, so, far reaching policy, I adore thee,
Will hug thee as my darling
Shallow fools
Dive not into the pitch of regular statists.
Henceforth my stratagem's of scorn and hatred
Shall kill in smiles. I will not strike and frown,
But laugh and murder.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Welcome, are we safe?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Most free from interruption: the lord Velasco is newly entered the court; I have given the watch word that they ply him mainly; the conclusion (I know cannot but break off in hurleburly.

sp.speaker: Alph,
sp.l: Good, good, I hate him mortally. 'twas he
Slaved me to th' hangman's axe: but now go on;
Petruchi is the man, you say, must stand
The champion of her lust.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: There may be yet virtuous intention even in bad actions, in lewd words, I urge no further than likelihoods may inform.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Phew, that's thy nobleness: but now Muretto,
The eye of luxury speaks loud in silence.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Why look ye, sir, I must confess I observed some odd amorous glances, some sweet familiar courteous toying smiles; a kind of officious boldness in him, princelike and queenlike allowance of that boldness in him again; sometimes I might warily overhear her whispers. But what of all this? There might be no harm meant.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Fie, no, the grafting of my forehead, nothing else.
Grafting, grafting, Muretto, a most gentlemanlike exercise; a very mystery belongs to't.
And now and then they walk thus, arm in arm, twist fingers: ha. Would they not Muretto?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: 'Tis wondrous fit a great Queen should be supported, sir; and for the best lady of 'em all, to discourse familiarly with her supporter, is courtly and passing innocent.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: She and Petruchi did so?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: And at her passing to her private lodgings, attended only with her lady in ordinary. Petruchi alone went in before her.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Is't true! Went in before her! Canst prove that?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Your majesty is too quick, too apprehensive of the worst: I meant he performed the office of an usher.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Guilty apparently: monstrous woman! Beast!
Were these the fruits of her dissembling tears!
Her puling, and her heart sighs. But, Muretto.
I will be swift Muretto, swift and terrible.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: I am such another coxcomb; oh my side too.
Yet faith, let me persuade ye; I hope your wife is virtuous.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Virtuous? The devil she is, 'tis most impossible.
What kiss and toy, wink, prate, yet be virtuous?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: Why not sir? I think now a woman may lie four or five nights together with a man, and yet be chaste; though that be very hard, yet so long as 'tis possible, such a thing may be.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: I have it, we'll confer; let's stand aside.

sp.stage: Enter Bufo and another groom with wine, both drunk; Bufo handing Velasco by the shoulders.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Not drink more? By this hand you shall drink eleven whole healths, if your cap be wool or beaver; and that's my resolution.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: 'Sfoot, eleven score, without dishonour be it spoken to any man's person out of this place.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Prithee, I can no more, 'tis a profession
I dare not practice, nay, I will not.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: How will not? Not her queenships health?
Hark ye, thy stinking and unwholesome words —
Will not — you will not — you say you will not?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I say so, pray be answered.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.l: Pox of all flinchers; if a' say 'a will not,
Let him choose, like an arrant dry lord as he is.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Give me the bowl, I must be valiant.
You, sirrah, man at arms; here's a carouse
To the King, the Queen, and myself.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.l: Let't come, I ll have that i'faith,
Sweet, sweet, sweet, captain.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Hold, give the lord first, drink it up lord, do, ump.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Away I say, I am not in the tune.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Tune, tune? 'sblood, d'ye take us for fiddlers, scrappers, rhyme canters by tune? By this light, I'll scourge ye like a town top: look ye, I am urged — ump — and there's a side blow for ye, like a sober thing as ye are.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: Well done i'faith, precious captain.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Darest thou do this to me knowing who I am?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Yes, in the way of daring, I dare kick you thus, thus, sir up and down. There's a jolt on the bum too: how d'ye like it?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: 'Tis well! You use the privilege of the place.
There was a time the best of all this court
Durst not have lift a hand against me then.
But I must bear it now.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Is not this strange Muretto?

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: I can scantly credit mine own eyes: the captain follows his instructions perfectly.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Not drink? Mahound, infidel.
I will fillip thy nose, spit in thy face,
Mongrel; brave, a commander, ●a?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: O woman-woman-woman.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: That's a lie, a stark one, 'tis known I ne'er was a woman in my life. I am weary beating of him, and can stand no longer. Groom, kick him thou up and down in my behalf; or by this flesh I'll swinge you, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.l: Come aloft, jackanapes: come aloft; sirrah.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Why sure Velasco dares not fight.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: It must be some or other hath bewitched him.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Avaunt, I saw twelve dozen of cuckolds in the middle region of the air, galloping on a black jack, eastward ho. It is certain that every dozen went for a company, and they are now become a corporation. Aries and Taurus, the bull and the ram, two head signs, shall be henceforth their recognisances, set up in the grand hall of their politic convocations — whirr, whirr, there, there, just under the rainbow ambles Mercury, the thin bearded thief that stole away the draper's wife, while the good man was made drunk at the stillyard, at a beaver of Dutch bread and Rhenish wine, and lay all night in pure holland in's stockings and shoes. P●sh, talk not to me, I will maintain against the universities of both the Indies, that one alderman's horse is more right worshipful, than any six constables, brown bills and all. Now, now, now, my brains burn in sulphur, and thus will I stalk about; and swim through a whole element of dainty, neat, brisk, rich claret, canary, or maligo. Am not I Pynto, have not I hiren here? What art thou, a full moon, or a moon calf?

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis a dry stockfish, that must be beaten tender.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Was ever man so much a slave as I?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Does Saturn wince? Down with him, let Charles his wain run over his North pole; it shall be justified too.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: Now, sir, having taken a little breath, have at ye once more, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Clubs, clubs, I have been the death of two brewer's horses, and two catchpoles, myself, and now be tried by two fools and ten knaves: oh monstrous base, horrible; is my lord passed recovery?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Hold, prithee, fellow hold, I have no sword,
Or if I had, I dare not strike again.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Uds bones, were ye an invincible Armado,
I'd pound ye all like brown paper rags.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.l: Let me be strucken blind! The shame of fate;
Velasco, baffled, and not dare to strike!
Dogs, drunken dogs, I'll whip ye to your kennels.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Nay good, forbear.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Bilbo come forth and show thy fox's tail.
Nay, nay, give me liquor, and I'll fight like a roarer.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Keep standing ho; the almanac says plainly 'tis no season to be let blood, the sign is mortal. Hold!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Yes I command. Uncivil ill bred beasts.
How dares ye turn our palace to a booth?
How dare the proudest of ye all lift up
A hand against the meanest of those creatures
Whom we do own for ours? Now, now you spit
The ancient rancour of you bitter galls
Wherewith you strove to wound us heretofore.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: We are abused, my lord.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Fellow, thou liest.
Our royal eyes beheld the pride and malice
Of thee Velasco; who in hate to us
Deniest to honour our remembrance, though
But in a pledged health.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: Therein I was wronged.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, therein all thy cunning could not hide
The rage of thy malicious heart to us;
Yet know, for trial of thy love we caused
This onset, we will justify the height
Of thy disgraces; what they did was ours.
Hence coward, baffled, kicked, despised and spurned.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.l: Hang thyself; a pox on thee.
sp.stage: Exit Alphonso, Muretto, Pynto, Bufo, groom.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.l: O you're undone: what devil,
Hag, or witch
Hath stolen your heart away?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Not fight 'tis enough to shame us all.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Happy was I, that living lived alone,
Velasco was a man then, now is none.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Is't even so, no man now; then I smell how things stand: I'll lay my life, his lady sweet heart hath given him the gleek, and he in return hath gelded himself, and so both lost his courage and his wits together.

sp.stage: Enter Queen, Almado, Collumello, Petruchi and Herophil.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Speak o'er the words again; and good my lord
Be sure you speak the same, the very words;
Our Queen, our virtuous Queen; was't so?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Just so;
And was withal in carriage so most kind,
So princely, that I must do wrong to gratitude,
In wanting action to express his love.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I am the happiest she that lives. Petruchi,
Was I mistook or no? Why good my lords,
Observe it well. There is a holy league
Confirmed and ratified 'twixt love and fate.
This sacred matrimonial tie of hearts,
Called marriage, has divinity within't.
Prithee, Almado, tell me, smiled the King
When he commended to me?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Madam, yes;
And affably concluded all in this;
Commend us, and report us as you find.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: For love's sakes, no man prattle of distrust.
It shall be treason whosoever says
The King's unkind. My thinks I am all air,
My soul has wings.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And we are all o'erjoyed
In this sweet reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: We'll visit him (My lords) in some rich mask
Of rare device, as thus; pish, now I think on't,
The world yields not variety enough
Of cost, that's worthy of his royal eyes,
Why Herophil?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Here, madam.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now beshrew me
But I could weep for anger — if 'twere possible
To get a chariot cut out of a rock,
Made all of one whole diamond, drawn all on pavements
Of pearls and amber, by four ivory steeds
Of perfect crystal; this were worth presenting.
Or some bright cloud of sapphires — fie you are all
So dull, you do not love me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You're transported
To strange impossibilities: our service
Shall wait upon your happiness.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay, nay,
I know you laugh at me, and well you may;
I talk I know not what. I would 'twere fit
To ask one question of ye.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Madam, any thing.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You'll swear that I am idle, yet you know
'Tis not my custom; look upon me well;
Am I as fair as Herophil?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, madam,
Or any other creature else alive.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You make me blush in troth. O would the King
Could see me with your eyes. Or would I were
Much courser than I am to all the world;
So I might only seem more fair to him.
See here come more. Velasco, thou art welcome.
Welcome kind Lodovico. You I know
Bring fresh supplies of comfort; do not cloud
Your news with circumstance: say, doth the King
Expect me? Yes, good man, I know he does.
Speak briefly, good my lord, and truly.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Madam, take all at once, he is the King;
And Kings may do their pleasures.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: True, Velasco.
But I have from my heart forgotten remembrance
Of former passages, the world is changed:
Is a' not justly royal?

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Would a' were, I wish it for your sake madam, but my wishes and his inclinations are quite opposite.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: What said you, Lodovico?

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Thus Petruchi. Velasco hath been by the King disgraced, by his minions abused, baffled, they justified by the King in't. In a word; Alphonso is, and will be the scourge of Arragon.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I'll stop my ears, they sha'not let in poison,
Rank treacherous searching poison.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis impossible; but now I see
You're all agreed to curse me in the height
Of my prosperities. O that at once
I could have leave to die and shun the times.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: His excellent majesty by me commends to your royal hands this letter, madam.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Why thus I kiss,
And kiss again; welcome, whate'er it speaks.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: That you may all conceive (My lords) the Kings hearty zeal to unity and goodness, he by me entreats your attendance on the Queen to him: to you signior, Petruchi, he sends this diamond from his own finger.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: You strike me into wonder.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p:
I should excuse his highness'
violence to you, my lord Velasco; but he says, that your own indiscretion deserved your late reproof: and further, (Pardon me that I mince not the sum of his injunction) he says your cowardice is now so vulgarly palpable, that it cannot stand with his honour to countenance so degenerating a spirit.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: I thank him; yet, if you remember well;
Both he and you proved me another man.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The sweetest letter that ever was writ:
Come we must to the King — how! 'tis my ring,
The first ring that I ever gave the King.
Petruchi, I must have it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Twas the King sent it:
I mean to yield it back again.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No I will.
And in exchange take that of equal value:
But not with me, 'cause it comes from my husband.
Let's slack no time, this day shall crown our peace.
sp.stage: Exit all but Velasco and Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.l: You see my lord how the world goes.
What your next course?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: Would I could leave myself, I am unfit
For company of men: art thou my friend?

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: I cannot tell what I am, your patient humour indeed persuades me I am nothing.

Lady's little puppy dogs shortly will break your shins with milksops, and you dare not cry, come out cur. Faith tell me for our wonted friendship's sake; hath not this madam sweet heart of yours a share in your metamorphosis?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: You are unkind, as much as in a thought,
To wrong her virtue. Lodovico, no;
I have resolved never to fight again.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: 'Tis a very safe resolution: but have you resolved never to be beaten again?

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: That goodly sound of gallant valiant man
Is but a breath, and dies as soon as uttered.
I'll seek my fame henceforward in the praise
Of sufferance and patience, for rash manhood
Adds only life to cruelty, yet by cruelty
Takes life away, and leaves upon our souls
Nothing but guilt, while patience if it be
Settled, doth even in bondage keep us free.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Excellent morality; but good my lord, without more circumstance, the cause, let me know the ground and cause on't.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.l: My will, or if you please my cowardice,
More ask not, more, I vow, you shall not know.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: O fie, fie, I were better be the hangman's deputy, than my lord Velasco's gentleman usher; all the streets as I pass hoot at me, and ask me if I be so valiant as my master the coward; they swear their children carry wooden daggers to play a prize with him, and there's no talk but of the arrant coward Velasco.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: I care not, let 'em talk.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Care not? By these hilts, I had rather than a hundred ducats, I had but as much spirit: as to have drawn upon a couple of men in gingerbread, which a huckster's crooked legged whoreson ape held up, and swore they were two taller fellows than you are.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Your readiest way were to get you into a cloister; for there's no going to court:

sp.speaker: Mop:
sp.p: Yes, to have our brains rubbed out with the heel of a brown manchet.

sp.speaker: Velas.
sp.p: As, you're my friend forbear to come more near me.

sp.speaker: Lodou.
sp.p: Gone so quickly? Mopas I'll find out this mystery, and thou shalt be the instrument.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p:
Shall I? Why agreed, let me
alone for an instrument, be it a wind or stringed instrument, I'll sound at one end or other I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Are all things ready as we gave charge?

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Yes all, and the face of the heavens are passing favourable.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Bufo, be it thy care, the watch word given,
To seize Petruchi suddenly.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: If the devil be not in him, I'll make him fast enough.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Mean time we'll take our place, they are at hand.
Some sound our choicest music t'entertain
This Queen with all the seeming forms of state.

sp.stage: Enter Queen supported by Petruchi, Herophil, Collumello, Almada, and Muretto.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: All joy to Aragon's great King.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You strive to act in words (My lords) but we ourselves
Endeavour rather how to speak in act.
Now is a time of peace of amity.
The Queen is present; lady, seat you here,
As near, as if we placed you in our heart,
Where you are deep enthroned.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: As you in mine,
So may I ever live in yours, my lord.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How so? You are too charitable now,
That cover but equality in love;
A cold, a frozen love; for I must think
The streams of your affections are dried up,
Or running from their wonted channels, range
In lawless paths of secrecy and stealth;
Which makes us love you more.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I would your words
Dissented not from your resolved thoughts
For then (If I mistake not) you would feel
Extremity of passion, which indeed
Is noble jealousy.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Are you so plain?
I thank you madam; lend me your fair hand,
What's here? O my presages! Whence got you this ring?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: This ring, my lord?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: This ring, my lord!
By honour's reverend crest 'tis time to wake.
Art thou not pale, Petruchi?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gracious, sir.
This is the ring you sent me by Muretto,
Which 'cause it came from you, the Queen would needs
Exchange it for another of her own.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: True, 'cause it came from me, I take it so,
And grant ye, know the word. 'tis won and lost.

sp.stage: Enter a guard, Bufo with them seize Petruchi; Pynto the Queen.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: What mean ye, hellhounds? Slaves, let go my sword.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Keep in your chaps, and leave scolding, my small friend, 'tis now no time to wrangle or to roar.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Nay, nay, with what you please I am content.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What means your highness?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Wrong not majesty
With such unnoble rigour.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: O, my lords,
The weight of all this shame falls heaviest here
In my afflicted bosom. Madman like
I would not credit, what mine ears had heard,
From time to time of that adulterous woman.
For this have I lived widowed from her bed,
Was deaf to proofs, to oaths, and ever thought
That whoredom could not suit herself so trimly
On virtues outside. But Petruchi there
Hath a loud speaking conscience, can proclaim
Her lust, and my dishonour

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Grant me hearing.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Away with him to prison, make him fast
On pain of all your lives.

sp.speaker: Buf.
sp.p: Come, sir, there is no playing fast and loose, which fit a ducat now.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But what now for the Queen?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: As she deserves.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Our law requires a clear and open proof,
And a judicial trial.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Yes to subjects
It does, but who among you dares speak justice
Against your natural sovereign? Not one.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.p: Your majesty hath most wisely considered that point.

sp.speaker: Muret.
sp.p: I have stood silent all this while, and cannot but with astonishment and unutterable grief bear a share of sadness in these disasters. But, madam, be not altogether dejected on your part: there is more mercy in this sovereign prince, then that you should any way distrust.

sp.speaker: Qu.
